title: added error msg when llm is not explicitly passed
body:
# Description

If llm was not explicitly passed then code was trying to make request through Open Ai gpt3.5 turbo by default which may not be available and will throw an authentication error. It is hard to diagnose the problem without proper error message.
We didn't use the resolve_llm function from utils.py because it can roll down to mock LLM which won't help us in this question generation task.

Fixes # (issue)
we added None check, and if LLM is not explicitly passed then we will raise an error to pass the llm

title: Define Vertex examples as a Sequence
body:

title: update docs
body:
This PR adds ingestion pipeline to the docs, and cleans up various other aspects of the docs in relation to the changes in v0.9

One particularly thorny issue was

```
text_splitter = SentenceSplitter(chunk_size=512, chunk_overlap=10)
service_context = ServiceContext.from_defaults(node_parser=text_splitter)
```

so I added `text_splitter` as a kwarg to the service context, just to make the syntax less confusing (even though under the hood, the text splitter extends the node parser class)

title: Updated limit for deleting weaviate objects
body: While using weaviate via the vector store, we found out that we can delete only 100 objects at once using the delete functions, so we searched through the weaviate class in the llama index library to find out that the delete function first calls the get function for fetching the required objects based on the parameters user has passed. By default the get query returns 100 objects only thus resulting in deletion of only 100 objects. We have modified the get query and added a "with_limit" attribute to mention the limit of objects it can return. We have set it to 10000, as weaviate supports only retrieval of 10000 objects at once.

title: Subclass getstate from pydantic's BaseModel to fix cannot pickle and unpickle TextNode
body:
# Description

Cannot pickle and then unpickle TextNode object. This is due to `BaseComponent`'s `__getstate__` completely overwrites `pydantic.BaseModels`'s `__getstate__`. Example:

```python
import pickle
from llama_index.schema import TextNode

abc = TextNode(text="abc")

# save ok
with open("abc.pkl", "wb") as fo:
    pickle.dump(abc, fo)

# error when load
with open("abc.pkl", "rb") as fi:
    data = pickle.load(fi)
```

Stack trace:
```
File ~/.cache/pypoetry/virtualenvs/llama-index-Jalitqr9-py3.9/lib/python3.9/site-packages/pydantic/main.py:416, in pydantic.main.BaseModel.__setstate__()

KeyError: '__dict__'
```

## Type of Change

title: Add Sparse Embedding to BaseNode Class
body:
# Description

This PR adds an optional parameter to the BaseNode class `sparse_embedding`. This is made to support by default the growing number of RAG systems that include traditional sparse-vector search methods (ex. Okapi BM25). 

To provide extended functionality for this change, I edited the PineconeVectorStore class to support adding nodes with existing sparse vectors in the `add` class method.

title: feat(llm): OpenLLM
body:
Signed-off-by: Aaron <29749331+aarnphm@users.noreply.github.com>

cc @parano

# Description

🎉 OpenLLM 🤝 Llama_index

[OpenLLM](https://github.com/bentoml/OpenLLM) is an open-source platform designed to facilitate the deployment and operation of large language models (LLMs) in real-world applications. With OpenLLM, you can run inference on any open-source LLM, deploy them on the cloud or on-premises, and build powerful AI applications.

It includes supports for a wide range of open-source LLMs and model runtimes, including but not limited to Mistral, Llama2, StableLM, Falcon, Dolly, Flan-T5, ChatGLM, and StarCoder.
It also has support for token streaming, quantization, and continuous batching (via vLLM), which can significantly increase the total throughput of LLMs.

With this in mind, this integration to Llama_index brings in two new `LLM`: `OpenLLM` and `OpenLLMAPI`.

For running locally with `OpenLLM`, it will requires user to install `openllm[vllm]` on GPU and `openllm` if running on CPU.

```python
from llama_index.llms.openllm import OpenLLM
llm = OpenLLM('HuggingFaceH4/zephyr-7b-alpha')

llm.complete('I love you')
await llm.acomplete('I love you')

for it in llm.stream_chat(
    [
        ChatMessage(
            role="system", content="You are acting as Ernest Hemmingway."
        ),
        ChatMessage(role="user", content="Hi there!"),
        ChatMessage(role="assistant", content="Yes?"),
        ChatMessage(role="user", content="What is the meaning of life?"),
    ]
):
    print(it.message.content, flush=True, end="")

async for llm.astream_complete("The meaning of life is"): print(it.delta, flush=True, end='')
```

With an OpenLLM server running elsewhere or on [BentoCloud](https://www.bentoml.com/cloud), users will need to install `openllm-client` and use `OpenLLMAPI`:

```python
from llama_index.llms.openllm import OpenLLMAPI

llm = OpenLLM(address='remote.server:3000')
```

> [!NOTE]
> For `OpenLLMAPI`, if `OPENLLM_ENDPOINT` is set, then the following can be achieved:
> ```python
> llm = OpenLLMAPI()
> ```

All async and sync variation of chat and completeion message is supported for both `OpenLLM` and `OpenLLMAPI`.

title: bugfix: added entry for callback to clear _node_data_buffer
body:
# Description
In `OpenInferenceCallbackHandler`, both `self._query_data_buffer` and `self._node_data_buffer` grows persistently and require manual clearing.
In production env, we need to provide a callback to `OpenInferenceCallbackHandler` for logging and clearing `node_data_buffer`, but `node_data_buffer` is out of access in callback, which leave it grows out of control.
```python
class ParquetCallback:
    ...
    def __call__(
        self,
        query_data_buffer: List[QueryData],
    ) -> None:
        if len(query_data_buffer) > self._max_buffer_length:
            ...
            self._batch_index += 1
            query_data_buffer.clear()  # ⚠️ clear the buffer or it will keep growing forever!
```

# Fixes
pass `self._node_data_buffer` to `callback` function, so it can clear it periodically
```python
    def end_trace(...) -> None:
        if trace_id == "query":
            ...
            if self._callback is not None:
                self._callback(self._query_data_buffer, self._node_data_buffer)
```

## Type of Change

title: Optimized function schema message for `ToolMetadata`
body:
# Description
Let's say we define a super simple schema
```python
class MySchema(BaseModel):
    input: Optional[str]
```
## Before
`ToolMetadata.fn_schema_str` returns:
```python
{'title': 'FnSchema', 'description': 'Default tool function Schema.', 'type': 'object', 'properties': {'input': {'title': 'Input', 'type': 'string'}}}
```
***Problem:*** It contain too many information such as `title`, and it's not a valid `Json`, because it simply produced by `str(model.schema())`
## After
`ToolMetadata.fn_schema_str` returns:
```json
{"type": "object", "properties": {"input": {"title": "Input", "type": "string"}}}
```

## Usage Pattern
use it in query_engine
```python
query_engine_tools = [
    RetrieverTool(
        retriever=vs_retriever,
        metadata=ToolMetadata(
            name="useless tool", 
            description="super useless",
             fn_schema=MySchema
        ),
    ),
]
```
when we prompt tool to LLM by
```python
def get_react_tool_descriptions(tools: Sequence[BaseTool]) -> List[str]:
    """Tool."""
    tool_descs = []
    for tool in tools:
        tool_desc = (
            f"> Tool Name: {tool.metadata.name}\n"
            f"Tool Description: {tool.metadata.description}\n"
            f"Tool Args: {tool.metadata.fn_schema_str}\n"
        )
        tool_descs.append(tool_desc)
    return tool_descs
```
`tool.metadata.fn_schema_str` is the description of schema that LLM use to understand how to call the tool

body:
# Description

First tutorial guide for MM RAG Evaluation:

- Added `MultiModalRetrieverEvaluator` for being able to evaluate a mm retriever and specifying whether `images` or `text` retrieval wants to be evaluated
- These should be done separately similar to the reason why we have `top_k` params for both text and image cases
- Added `RetrievalEvalMode` to specify the kind of retrieval eval being done: `image` or `text`
    - Added a `mode` field to `RetrievalEvalResult` that defaults to `text` 
- Hacky Add: In order to impl the idea of using generated image summaries as text embeddings for images rather than CLIP default (which btw, works well in the example of the notebook)... had to do some hacky stuff. TODO: this needs to get cleaned up, but wanted to get this on people's radar/eyes in case someone else knows of an already cleaner way to do this.

https://docs.pydantic.dev/1.10/usage/schema/#modifying-schema-in-custom-fields

The new version requires the object to be a pydnatic object 🤔

title: remove commonly unpicklable entries
body:
# Description

Tiktoken is famously un-picklable, but it's used all across LlamaIndex.

However, with a sneaky wave of a wand (and relying on `BaseComponent` inheritance), we can fix this by removing unpicklable entries.

This probably won't cover every edge case, but it gets most.

Tested with `pickle.dumps(index)` and `pickle.dumps(index.as_query_engine())`.

Fixes https://github.com/run-llama/llama_index/issues/8835

## Type of Change

- [x] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)

body:
# Description
The `to_openai_multi_modal_payload` utility function is trying to create `image_content` first by looking for `image_url` within the `metadata` of the `ImageDocument`. However, I believe it should be reading directly from the `image_url` field as the `load_image_urls` loads urls from a list and converts them to `ImageDocuments` with `image_url` being populated.

title: improve multimodal retrieval and delete
body:
# Description

MultiModalVectorStoreIndex had some issues with retrieval and deletion. This PR fixes both by

- ensuring duplicate node ids are not inserted into ref_doc_info
- ensures the proper node type is loaded when fetching from a vector store
- no longer forces users to use the docstore/index store, since most images should just be paths or URLs anyways (if this is an issue for users, they can always enable the docstore)
